The CMA has highlighted concerns in areas with a GUPPI of 0% to 5%, opting for a threshold of 2.5%. This is inconsistent with precedent cases which have used a GUPPI threshold range of 5-10% and is thus beyond our range of anticipated scenarios; leading Sainsbury to note - with justification - that the CMA has moved the “goal posts”.

BE11:19am

Hooray! GUPPI thresholds.

Excel Developer @SupposeToBeWorking... good one.
wayneJ The model is (1) Walmart take big writedown - but it is ok as their US business has surprised on upside (2) Sell to UK PE for £1 (3) PE (retail turnaround specialists) dump stock to generate cash (4) extract 'special dividend' (5) put co into administration (6) Pension has to be dealt with by govt (6) Outrage in newspapers (7) Parliamentary enquiry with Frank Fields making acerbic comments (8) Statement by govt 'Lessons have been learnt, long time ago, more important to look to future'
BE11:20am

 1% synergy offset - The CMA states that it disagrees with the parties’ view of the scale and potential offsetting impact of the merger synergies, opting to offset c.1% from its GUPPI analysis.
 Provisional remedies look challenging - Based on our analysis, disposals of much more than 200 stores (c.f the c.330 implied by the CMA) would challenge the parties to find willing and acceptable buyers.
 Deal progress impeded with Sainsbury likely to challenge - Given the scale of the differences between the CMA’s provisional findings and the views of the parties (which are more closely aligned with our own analysis), it seems unlikely that the deal will proceed on the intended timescale. That said, we would expect Sainsbury to contest the findings in the available time before the issuance of the final report on 29 April and to consider a legal challenge thereafter, given the unprecedented nature of the CMA’s provisional findings.

VV75 9) Corbyn says nationalise all supermarkets and he supplies them from his allotment
wayneJ (PS I observe Homebase stores rather busy recently. One might observe rather a lot of Australian sourced stock being sold at attractive prices). (Clues that some of the stuff is Australian include 'tough enough for Australian weather')

BE11:21am

BE11:21am

Although the CMA might conceivably be persuaded to think differently by the time of the CMA’s final report, our central assumption would be that this is unlikely to happen. We therefore assume that the proposed merger will have to be abandoned – even though Sainsbury and ASDA may not openly accept the inevitability of that outcome at this stage.

We think that blockage by the CMA would have been considered a very pessimistic outcome at one point – last summer we struggled to find many investors who doubted that the proposed merger would be passed by the CMA. However, today’s development perhaps comes as less of a surprise today after the public disagreement (on the timelines of the merger investigation) between Sainsbury/ASDA and the CMA in December. Ultimately, we believe that last night’s closing share price still discounted a certain percentage likelihood that the merger would come to fruition.

Our valuation of Sainsbury is based on a 67% chance of the proposed merger proceeding – and a valuation of 250p without a merger and 385p with a merger (see More cautious, but still see upside, 16 January). Putting these metrics together generates a valuation of 340p – hence our price target. In light of the greater clarity post the release of the CMA’s provisional findings, we will need to revisit these views.

BE11:26am

We stated repeatedly that we could not predict the UK Competition & Markets Authority
(CMA) and today we see why. In provisional findings that potentially create retail history, the
CMA looks minded to reject the proposed merger of Sainsbury & Asda.
Whilst we need to see if Sainsbury and Asda can argue and legally challenge the CMA’s
findings, the deal looks to have suffered a mortal blow; the CMA struggles to see how
remedies can deliver its view of a competitive UK market.
Indeed, Sainsbury’s angry reaction to the CMA’s announcements, which we need to read in
detail, reflects the mood but also perhaps is a little detached. We believe it is bordering on
laughable for the Group to state; ‘We are surprised that the CMA would choose to reject the
opportunity to put money directly into customers' pockets’ when we always felt that 10%
price cuts on unspecified products on an unspecified timeframe was playing to the galleries.
Sainsbury looks like it has misunderstood the consumer and the CMA.
There is more water to potentially flow under the bridge on this one, but expect considerable
interest in songs sung by Ginger Rodgers today. For Sainsbury’s we see this as a major
blow and one that removes the merger premium and so we downgrade to SELL, noting its
laggard status in British supermarketing. For Wal-Mart this is a headache that requires plan
B, although we sense that there will be more smiles in Leeds than Holborn.
For the balance of the sector, we see this broadly encouraging, so allowing us to reiterate
our BUY stance on Tesco and our positive sentiment on Morrisons (HOUSE STOCK).

11:29 am
BE11:29am

Financial highlights
• The fall in capital values in the final quarter of has contributed to an NAV down 24% in the year to 312p, some way below our forecast at 338p.
• The fall in valuations over the year was 13.3%, with yields moving out by 62bp. The valuation decline appears to have been steady throughout the year with a 6.2% decline in H1 and a 7.6% decline in H2 including a 3.0% fall in the final quarter.
• The valuation move reflects the investment market moving to be based off current passing rents, rather than assumed future rental tones which we have doubted for some time. On a like-for-like basis, ERVs were down 3.9%.
• The fall in values has pushed LTV to 53% (FY17: 45%), and the Company will not be paying a final dividend (PHe: 1p).
• Intu sets out proposals to bring LTV back down below 50%: retaining the dividend “for the time being”; plus further disposals (£171m in 2018) although sales in the UK are “challenging” while offers have been received for assets in Spain (Intu share of investments: c£630m) which are being evaluated.
• A further 10% decline in valuations will need £1m of equity to cure.

FATDAZ @Pharma yes i think they are quite selective about locations places like Holt without a local rival and smaller shops in satellite towns and villages
Burt anything on Inmarsat please
BE11:30am

Peel Hunt Forecasts
• Looking forwards, we reduce our 2019 NAV forecast today by a further 5% to c274p. We place EPS under review and cut the dividend to 0p (from 4.5p).
• Shares trade on a 57% prospective NAV discount, but with no income support and a compromised capital structure there remains plenty to be cautious about, especially with respect to the potential impact on retail landlords from the re-basing of retail rents. Hold.

Operationally, INTU highlights a resilient performance, with LfL NRI +0.6% (FY17 +0.5%). With no detail as to the calculation methodology, we remain sceptical around the veracity of this figure, given retailer failures reduced NRI by -1.9% (CVAs/administrations impacted c.6% of the rent roll, although 72% of this has either rolled the rent or seen only a “small reduction”). There were 248 new lettings secured at an average +6% vs previous passing rent, while rent reviews were settled at +7% on average. Disposals and developments reduced NRI by £11.8m. Mgmt is guiding towards LfL NRI in 2019 of -1% to -2%, including the impact of House of Fraser, subject to no new material tenant failures (prev guidance +1%). Footfall across the portfolio was -1.6% vs the index -3.5%; retailer sales were -2.3%.

In an unscheduled trading update ahead of tomorrow's H1, McBride are guiding to FY19 PBT 10%-15% lower than FY18, driven by a less benign raw material environment than anticipated and rising distribution costs. This contrasts with expectations per consensus and JEFe of 14% growth and 18% growth respectively and implies FY19 PBT of £28m to £30m relative to consensus £38m and JEFe £39m.

A. M. (I have to say that 'One Blackfriars' looks rather awful)

11:42 am
BE11:42am

And the detail via Peel Hunt.

BE11:43am

This is not a sales issue, but relates to higher input, logistics and service costs. Input costs are likely to be £4m higher than previously expected, with oil related prices not falling as much as expected and bicarbonate (used in powders) prices c£2m higher than expected.
The company had hoped to be reducing logistics costs as the new business wins in Central Europe settled in. However, this continues to be an area of concern, exacerbated by having to move warehouse following notice being given by a 3rd party supplier. Overall distribution costs will be c£3m higher than expected. In addition, the distribution issues have reduced service levels, which has resulted in c£1m of customer penalties.

Pharma @Soundbuy, sounds like a jail sentence, in more ways than one.
BE11:43am

Outlook for next year
We will properly assess our forecasts for next year post the interims tomorrow. At this stage it is reasonable to assume that profits are greater than £30m assuming the company gets on top of the distribution issues, reduces the customer penalties and removes the losses from personal care.

BE11:58am

Lloyds Q4’18 results are 4% ahead of company consensus pre-tax ex remediation costs and 9% above our
expectations, driven by lower Costs and lower impairment. The key highlights are Capital return (effective 9.7%
yield) and Costs with management lowering the Cost guidance for 2019 after a good performance in 2018,
especially given disappointments across the sector. Although NII was 1% below expectations, with NIM down
1bp in Q4 vs Q3 to 2.92bps, the group continues to reiterate its medium-term stable NIM guidance of around
290bps. Other Income was 1% lower in FY’18 vs FY’17, a bit below the group’s stable guidance with Q4
coming in c4% below expectations. However, we believe that the lower revenue outcome in Q4 is offset by the
new cost guidance of sub £8bn in 2019 vs consensus of £8.1bn, which implies no downgrades to consensus
expectations. The share buyback was significantly ahead, at £1.75bn, versus consensus £1.2bn, equal to a 2.46p
dividend on top of the ordinary DPS of 3.21p leading to c9.7% yield combined. Our OW recommendation on
Lloyds is based on its under-appreciated capital generation, with the group generating 210bps in 2018 and
guiding to 170-200bp CT1 generation in 2019. This underpins the outlook for continued capital return, in our
view, and is a key difference relative to RBS, where generation is lower and the capital return is driven by a
one-time surplus. With TNAV at 53p, Lloyds trades at 1.1x P/TNAV for RoNAV of 15%. We remain OW.

BE12:00pm

Citi's Take — Underlying 4Q18 PBT £2.0bn is +4% yoy and 4% above consensus, albeit driven by lower loan losses (pre-provision profit is a 2% miss). Revenues are - 1% yoy and 2% below consensus, while costs are -3% yoy and 3% better than consensus. Statutory PBT of £1.0bn is well below consensus driven by another £0.2bn PPI charge. We view these as a mixed set of results, but we expect focus will be instead on the 2019 outlook statement and the buyback announcement, both of which are supportive. We have a Buy rating, target price 68p.

What a Difference 12 Months Makes

The disclosure that the Company will offer 46p a share in its distribution is a stark contrast to the position the Company was in 12 months ago.

That the turnaround has occurred in only 12 months of the OML18 transaction functioning according to plan underlines how compelling the investment was initially. We think that not only is this a just reward for those that have held their shares throughout that process, but it is also a sign of what we believe could yet come from the Company once it, via the operator group Eroton, is able to eliminate losses from the cluster export line.

The shareholders and investors will be pleased with the progress over the last 12 months, and today's news especially.
